item.title: The Germans are coming: August Sander's People of the 20th Century arrive at MoMA
item.trailText: Admired for their detail, wit and insight, Sander’s 619 photographs have been acquired my the Museum of Modern Art in New York
item.standFirst: From blind men on a bench, to carnival-goers in Cologne, the German photographer August Sander captured a unique portrait of life in the 20th century. Admired for their detail, wit and insight, his 619 photographs, taken over 60 years, have now been acquired by the Museum of Modern Art in New York

displayImages.caption:
Artists’ Carnival in Cologne, 1931
Sander believed that society was organised into a hierarchy of occupations and social types, from farm labourers to circus performers, businessmen to aristocrats

displayImages.caption:
Farming Family, 1913-14
Around 1,800 negatives for People of the 20th Century have survived, as well as Sander’s notes and plans. The first publication of the work was confiscated by the Nazis and 40,000 negatives were destroyed in the bombing of his studio in 1944

displayImages.caption:
Publisher Kurt Neven DuMont, 1933
Despite the project spanning some 60 years, Sander still considered it unfinished and didn’t publish the completed book during his lifetime. His son Gunther worked on the archive and published the images under the title that August had originally planned, Menschen des 20. Jahrhunderts (People of the Twentieth Century), in Munich in 1980

All photographs: August Sander/Sander family/MOMA
